lens.lens_summary: This lens reveals how a project-driven guest (art gallery in Chelsea) discovers Split Lease through Craigslist cross-posting, enters a human-mediated intake funnel, and how the Hook Model's Trigger-Action-Reward-Investment cycle maps onto the guest's journey from first external trigger through active lease habit formation.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Tyler discovered Split Lease not through the platform itself but through a Craigslist posting by host Nina. He searched 'Chelsea' on Craigslist and found a listing that linked to Split Lease. This is a classic external trigger (Eyal Ch 2: relationship/earned trigger). The platform's discovery relies on cross-posted content on established marketplaces, not on its own brand recognition. Tyler had zero prior awareness of Split Lease — his mental model was 'Craigslist room search' and Split Lease appeared as an intermediary he had to evaluate separately.

user_state.emotional_state: Goal-oriented but cautious. Tyler is in California, planning a return to NYC for a specific art gallery project. He is time-pressured (needs space by December 1st) but not desperate — he has a clear use case and budget.
user_state.knowledge_level: Zero knowledge of Split Lease as a platform. Understands Craigslist. Knows the host (Nina) posted at $1800/month for Mon-Fri. Does not understand Split Lease's nights-of-the-week model or how matching works.
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing with intent. He responded to a specific listing, which shows higher commitment than random browsing, but he has not committed to Split Lease as a platform.
user_state.data_available: Craigslist click-through, initial contact (call/text to Split Lease agent)

reasons: Tyler found a specific listing on Craigslist — if that listing is unavailable for his dates, he has no reason to stay on Split Lease
He has no understanding of what Split Lease is or why it's better than direct Craigslist transactions
The human-mediated intake (phone call) is a high-friction discovery channel that doesn't scale
dropout_risk.evidence: Tyler at 09:33: 'on Craigslist summer, you know, I just clicked search for Chelsea. And then I saw that posting.' — discovery was Craigslist-first, not Split Lease-first. Eyal Ch 1: 'For new entrants to stand a chance, they can't just be better, they must be nine times better' because old habits (Craigslist search) die hard.

key_quotes.quote: On Craigslist summer, you know, I just clicked search for Chelsea. And then I saw that posting.
key_quotes.relevance: Discovery channel is Craigslist, not Split Lease. The platform is invisible — the listing is the trigger.

key_quotes.quote: Habit-forming technologies start changing behavior by first cueing users with a call-to-action. External triggers are embedded with information, which tells the user what to do next.
key_quotes.relevance: Tyler's external trigger was the Craigslist listing. Split Lease must ensure this trigger contains enough information to pull the guest into the platform funnel rather than prompting a direct message to the host.

key_quotes.quote: For new entrants to stand a chance, they can't just be better, they must be nine times better. Because old habits die hard and new products or services need to offer dramatic improvements to shake users out of old routines.
key_quotes.relevance: Tyler's old habit is Craigslist search. Split Lease must offer 9x value over Craigslist to form a new habit.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Tyler did not search on Split Lease — he searched on Craigslist and found one specific listing. The agent (Sabot) positioned himself as the search engine: 'based on what you will tell me, I would be able to do the search and find what fits you best' (05:47). This reveals a critical gap: the platform's search functionality is being replaced by human labor. The Hook Model's Action phase (Ch 3) requires the action to be as simple as possible — yet the current 'search' requires a phone call, information extraction, and manual matching by an agent.

user_state.emotional_state: Cooperative but slightly impatient. Tyler is in California dealing with poor phone connection (AirPods issues), wants this to be quick: 'I'm not going to waste a lot of your time' (05:40).
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows his requirements clearly: Chelsea location, Saturday-Wednesday nights, ~$2000/month, at least 2 months, private bathroom, single occupancy, willing to self-clean.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating. He came for one specific listing but is open to alternatives if the agent can find them.
user_state.data_available: Location preference, date range, budget, duration, amenity requirements, flexibility parameters

reasons: Search is entirely human-mediated — if the agent doesn't find options fast enough, Tyler will search elsewhere
Tyler's requirements are specific (Chelsea, weekends included) which may not match available inventory
No self-service search means Tyler has zero control over the process
dropout_risk.evidence: Agent at 15:37: 'there's no point of talking about apartment until that apartment is available to your specific days' — the guest is told to wait. Eyal Ch 3 (Action): 'the ease of performing an action' is a key factor. A phone call for search is the opposite of easy.

key_quotes.quote: Based on what you will tell me, I would be able to do the search and find what fits you best.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent IS the search engine. This is human-mediated search that cannot scale and creates dependency on the agent, not the platform.

key_quotes.quote: Companies leverage two basic pulleys of human behavior to increase the likelihood of an action occurring: the ease of performing an action and the psychological motivation to do it.
key_quotes.relevance: Making a phone call to search is high-friction. The platform must reduce the action to something as easy as a Craigslist search filter.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Tyler evaluated Nina's listing based on the Craigslist post (price $1800, Mon-Fri days) before ever speaking to Split Lease. His evaluation criteria emerged during the call: location (Chelsea, Manhattan), price (~$2000/month), days (Saturday-Wednesday), private bathroom, and whether it was a room or full apartment. The agent spent the entire call extracting these criteria — information that should be surfaceable through the listing page itself. Eyal's Variable Reward (Ch 4) applies here: the listing page should offer 'rewards of the hunt' — discovering that a space matches your needs should feel like finding treasure, not like filling out a form.

user_state.emotional_state: Hopeful but hedging. Tyler likes the Chelsea listing but acknowledges his day requirements differ from what Nina posted. He's managing expectations.
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows the listing price ($1800), knows it's for Mon-Fri, knows it's in Chelsea. Does NOT know if his Saturday-Wednesday schedule is feasible, does not know the host personally, has not seen virtual tour.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditionally interested. Would commit if days and price work out.
user_state.data_available: Listing photos (from Craigslist), posted price, posted days, location

reasons: Day mismatch between what Nina posted (Mon-Fri) and what Tyler needs (Sat-Wed) could kill the deal immediately
Tyler has not seen the space (virtual tour not yet arranged)
Price uncertainty — weekends might be more expensive (agent mentions this at 11:06)
dropout_risk.evidence: Agent at 10:46: 'she was saying for Mondays to Friday and you have a little different requirements.' Tyler at 10:25: 'around 2000... the space she posted 1800.' Price gap + day mismatch = two sources of uncertainty.

key_quotes.quote: Tell it tells you is the best I am an otherwise, depending on the space, you know, other places in Manhattan I would never consider.
key_quotes.relevance: Tyler has strong location preference. Chelsea is non-negotiable (for his art gallery project). The listing evaluation is location-first.

key_quotes.quote: Around 2000. I mean, I think, you know, the space she posted 1800.
key_quotes.relevance: Guest has anchored on the posted price. Any price increase during negotiation will feel like loss (Eyal Ch 4: variable reward should feel positive, not like being upsold).

key_quotes.quote: Variable rewards are one of the most powerful tools companies implement to hook users. Introducing variability multiplies the effect, creating a focused state.
key_quotes.relevance: The listing page should create a sense of discovery — revealing matching features progressively — rather than presenting a static wall of information.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Tyler never created a proposal himself — the agent is collecting proposal parameters on his behalf via phone call. The proposal parameters are: Chelsea location, Saturday-Wednesday nights, ~$2000/month, December start, at least 2 months, private bathroom, single occupancy, self-cleaning. In the Hook Model's Investment phase (Ch 5), the act of creating a proposal IS the investment — the guest puts in time, data, and effort that increases their commitment. But when an agent does it for them, the guest makes zero investment and therefore has zero switching cost.

user_state.emotional_state: Passive. Tyler is answering questions, not actively configuring a proposal. He's cooperative but not invested.
user_state.knowledge_level: Knows what he wants but does not know what's available. Cannot see real-time availability, pricing, or matching options.
user_state.commitment_level: Low. He has invested only a phone call. No data stored on the platform, no profile created, no proposal submitted.
user_state.data_available: All parameters collected by agent verbally — not stored in platform by guest

reasons: Guest has made zero platform investment — no account, no saved searches, no profile
Agent-mediated proposal creation means guest can easily ghost (just stop answering calls)
The guest is in California and won't be in NYC until December — long gap between intake and action
dropout_risk.evidence: Eyal Ch 5 (Investment): 'The investment phase increases the odds that the user will make another pass through the hook cycle in the future. The investment occurs when the user puts something into the product.' Tyler has put nothing into the platform. The agent holds all the value.

key_quotes.quote: I guess that gives me all the information I need to start working and getting some good for you.
key_quotes.relevance: The AGENT has all the information. The PLATFORM has none. If the agent leaves, the information is lost.

key_quotes.quote: Inviting friends, stating preferences, building virtual assets, and learning to use new features are all investments users make to improve their experience. These commitments can be leveraged to make the trigger more engaging, the action easier, and the reward more exciting with every pass through the hook cycle.
key_quotes.relevance: Tyler has stated preferences (location, days, budget, duration) but these are stored in the agent's notes, not the platform. The platform must capture these as guest investments.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: The call reveals that negotiation happens before any formal proposal exists. The agent negotiates availability and pricing on Tyler's behalf with host Nina. Tyler is told he needs to be flexible on days ('if it would be Sunday to Wednesday, it would be significantly easier' — 16:38) and that weekends might cost more (11:06). This is pre-negotiation — the terms are being shaped by the agent acting as intermediary. In the Hook Model, this maps to the space between Action and Reward — the guest has taken action (provided requirements) but has not yet received the reward (a matching space). The delay creates uncertainty that could either build anticipation (good) or frustration (bad).

user_state.emotional_state: Accommodating but firm on core needs. Tyler is willing to flex on days but not on location or budget ceiling.
user_state.knowledge_level: Understands that his preferred days may not match host availability. Does not know if alternatives exist.
user_state.commitment_level: Medium. He's invested time in the call and adjusted his requirements, showing willingness to negotiate.
user_state.data_available: Flexibility parameters, non-negotiables (Chelsea, ~$2000 max), acceptable day variations

reasons: Extended delay between call and resolution — Tyler is in California, won't return until December
If the agent fails to find a match, Tyler has no fallback within the platform
Negotiation is entirely opaque — Tyler cannot see what's happening
dropout_risk.evidence: Tyler at 17:44: 'I am flexible. If it has to be Sunday through Wednesday or Sunday through Thursday, I'm a little bit flexible.' — Guest is accommodating, but if no match materializes he'll revert to Craigslist. Eyal Ch 4: 'some people eventually lose their taste for certain experiences' — delayed rewards lose their power.

key_quotes.quote: I'm a little bit flexible, but it depends. Saturday through Wednesday night is the best for me is ideal, but I'm a little bit flexible depending on the other person's needs.
key_quotes.relevance: Guest willingness to negotiate is conditional. The platform must surface what flexibility enables (more options, better price) to make flexibility feel like an investment, not a concession.

key_quotes.quote: I need to shoot for 2000, but if it would be a little more, I will give you option to consider, then you will decide.
key_quotes.relevance: Agent frames price flexibility as choice, not pressure. This is good negotiation design that the platform should replicate.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address acceptance. The call ends before any proposal is submitted or accepted. However, the Hook Model provides a framework for what acceptance should feel like: it should be the Variable Reward moment — the culmination of the guest's search, the moment where uncertainty resolves into certainty. Eyal Ch 4: 'levels of the neurotransmitter dopamine surge when the brain is expecting a reward.' The acceptance moment must deliver a satisfying payoff for all the effort invested in discovery, search, evaluation, and negotiation.

user_state.emotional_state: Not reached in this call — projected as relief and excitement based on Hook Model reward theory.
user_state.knowledge_level: Would need to know: confirmed days, confirmed price, space details, lease terms.
user_state.commitment_level: Would be high at this point — guest has invested time, adjusted requirements, and agreed to terms.
user_state.data_available: Projected: agreed terms, payment authorization, lease documents

reasons: If the acceptance process is complex or unclear, the guest may hesitate at the final step
Payment authorization is a high-stakes moment that requires trust
dropout_risk.evidence: Eyal Ch 4: 'autonomy is essential — forced loops backfire.' The acceptance moment must feel like the guest's choice, not like they've been funneled into a commitment.

key_quotes.quote: What distinguishes the Hook Model from a plain vanilla feedback loop is the hook's ability to create a craving. Feedback loops are all around us, but predictable ones don't create desire.
key_quotes.relevance: Acceptance should not feel predictable/mechanical. It should feel like winning — the guest found the right space for their project.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address move-in. Tyler mentions he'll 'be back in the city early December' (18:24) and asks about virtual tours in the meantime (18:42). The Hook Model's Investment phase (Ch 5) suggests that move-in is when the guest makes their first physical investment in the space — this is the moment that transforms digital commitment into lived reality. Any gap between listing expectations and reality at this point would break the hook cycle.

user_state.emotional_state: Anticipated as high-anxiety — first time entering a shared space with a stranger's belongings.
user_state.knowledge_level: Would have seen virtual tour (if arranged) but physical reality is always different.
user_state.commitment_level: Fully committed (has paid, signed lease) — but emotional commitment is tested by first impressions.
user_state.data_available: House manual, check-in procedures, host communication

reasons: Reality vs. expectation gap could trigger buyer's remorse
Tyler is a creative professional (art gallery) — aesthetic expectations may be higher than average
First interaction with co-living arrangements may feel uncomfortable
dropout_risk.evidence: Tyler at 09:05: 'Art gallery.' — Tyler is an art professional. His aesthetic sensitivity is likely higher than average, making the physical space evaluation more critical. Eyal Ch 5: 'the investment phase isn't about users opening up their wallets and moving on with their day. Rather, the investment implies an action that improves the service for the next go-around.'

key_quotes.quote: If in the meantime, you or Nina can get the virtual tour of that space or another space.
key_quotes.relevance: Tyler wants to evaluate the space visually before committing to move-in. Virtual tours are a pre-investment that reduces move-in anxiety.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: The call reveals that Tyler's use case is the exact pattern that requires active lease management: he needs the space Saturday-Wednesday weekly, for at least 2 months, with holiday variations (Christmas in NYC, traveling 3-4 nights before Christmas). This is a nights-of-the-week lease with date exceptions — exactly the scenario that the Stays Manager and Date Change Tool are designed for. The Hook Model maps perfectly here: the weekly stay cycle IS the hook cycle. Each week: Trigger (upcoming stay notification) → Action (check in, notify host) → Variable Reward (the stay experience itself varies) → Investment (cleaning photos, review, date adjustments for next week). This is where habit formation happens or fails.

user_state.emotional_state: Would be routine-seeking. Tyler wants predictable weekly patterns for his art gallery project.
user_state.knowledge_level: Would need to understand: how to manage weekly stays, how to request date changes for holidays, how to communicate with host.
user_state.commitment_level: High once lease is active — but commitment is renewed weekly through the stay cycle.
user_state.data_available: Stay history, payment history, communication logs, cleaning photos, reviews

reasons: If the weekly stay management is cumbersome, Tyler will manage his schedule off-platform (texts, calls)
Holiday date changes (Christmas travel, pre-Christmas absence) require flexible date management tools
Self-cleaning agreement needs clear documentation to avoid disputes
dropout_risk.evidence: Tyler at 08:50: 'I'm going to be traveling for like three or four nights before Christmas, but yeah, I'm going to be in the city for Christmas.' — Active lease requires date change capability for exceptions. Eyal Ch 2 (Internal Triggers): 'When a product becomes tightly coupled with a thought, an emotion, or a pre-existing routine, it leverages an internal trigger.' The weekly commute pattern (California → NYC) is the routine that should trigger platform use.

key_quotes.quote: At least December and January, possibly more.
key_quotes.relevance: Open-ended lease duration means the active lease phase could last months. Each week is a hook cycle opportunity.

key_quotes.quote: You would be kind of cleaning after yourself for the person, that person would be cleaning for you.
key_quotes.relevance: The cleaning handoff is a weekly ritual that could become a hook cycle investment — cleaning photos prove care, build trust, load the next trigger (positive review).

key_quotes.quote: These commitments can be leveraged to make the trigger more engaging, the action easier, and the reward more exciting with every pass through the hook cycle.
key_quotes.relevance: Each weekly stay is an investment that should make the next stay better: stored preferences, established trust with host, accumulated reviews.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Human intermediary replaces platform at every phase — the agent performs discovery matching, search, evaluation guidance, proposal creation, and negotiation on behalf of the guest. The platform is invisible.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Tyler never interacts with the Split Lease platform during this call. Agent at 05:47: 'based on what you will tell me, I would be able to do the search.' Agent at 14:41: 'that gives me all the information I need to start working.' All value is captured by the agent, not the platform. Eyal Ch 5: investments must be stored in the product to create switching costs. Zero platform investment = zero switching cost.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Guest flexibility as negotiation currency — Tyler repeatedly offers flexibility on days (Saturday-Wednesday vs Sunday-Wednesday vs Sunday-Thursday) as the primary lever for matching. The platform needs to make flexibility visible and valuable, not just something the agent extracts verbally.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Tyler at 07:03: 'I'm a little bit flexible depending on the other person's needs.' Tyler at 17:44: 'I am flexible. If it has to be Sunday through Wednesday or Sunday through Thursday.' Agent at 18:13: 'That sounds much better because now I have something to work with.' Eyal Ch 3 (Action): ability is key — the platform must make expressing flexibility as easy as tapping alternative day combinations.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Weekly stay cycle as hook cycle — Tyler's use case (Saturday-Wednesday weekly for months) maps directly to Eyal's Hook Model. Each week: external trigger (upcoming stay notification) → action (check in) → variable reward (the stay experience) → investment (cleaning, review, date management). This is the highest-frequency interaction loop in the guest journey and therefore the highest-potential habit-forming zone.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Eyal Ch 1: 'a behavior that occurs with enough frequency and perceived utility enters the Habit Zone.' Tyler's weekly stays occur 4-5 nights per week for months. This is high-frequency. If the platform captures each stay cycle (check-in, cleaning photos, review), it enters the Habit Zone. Tyler at 13:53: cleaning exchange creates weekly ritual between guest and co-user.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Price anchoring creates negotiation tension — Tyler anchored on $1800 (Nina's posted price) but the agent suggests his requirements (weekends) may cost more. This anchoring effect means any price increase will feel like a loss, not a fair adjustment.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Tyler at 10:25: 'around 2000... the space she posted 1800.' Agent at 11:06: 'weekends usually more expensive.' Eyal Ch 4: variable reward must feel positive. Price increases during negotiation feel like anti-rewards. The platform must frame price changes as value-aligned, not as bait-and-switch.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: External-to-internal trigger migration failure risk — Tyler discovered Split Lease via an external trigger (Craigslist listing). The Hook Model requires migrating to internal triggers (the guest thinks of Split Lease when they need flexible housing). But with zero platform investment and agent-mediated everything, the guest's internal trigger will be 'call Sabot' not 'open Split Lease.'
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Eyal Ch 2: 'The ultimate goal of all external triggers is to propel users into and through the Hook Model so that, after successive cycles, they do not need further prompting from external triggers. When users form habits, they are cued by a different kind of trigger: internal triggers.' Tyler's only trigger is the agent. The platform must establish owned triggers (app notifications, email reminders) to migrate from human-dependency to platform-dependency.
